1.rationale:
Let’s review the current situation. After our last move upward, we ended up eating an apple (which was at (8,9)) so that we grew. Our snake now occupies (8,8) (the former head, which remains as a body segment because we grew) and (8,9) (our current head). Since we just grew, our tail cells do not move this turn, so (8,8) is still part of our snake. Meanwhile, the remaining apples are at (0,4), (1,3), (1,0), (0,7) and (8,7).

Our goal is to collect as many apples as possible while avoiding self-collision or running into walls. Notice that there is an apple at (8,7) which is vertically close to our head (only two rows down from (8,9)), but we cannot go DOWN immediately because that would place our head on (8,8), where our body currently resides.

Let’s review our available moves from our head at (8,9):

• UP is unavailable because that would take us to (8,10) which is off the board.
• DOWN would normally head us toward (8,7), but immediately moving DOWN would result in a collision with our tail at (8,8).
• LEFT would take us to (7,9). This move is safe and will allow our snake’s tail (currently at (8,8)) to move off in the subsequent update.
• RIGHT would take us to (9,9), which is also safe, and similarly our tail will then have moved away.

Both LEFT and RIGHT are safe, but which helps us position closer to the treasure apple at (8,7) in subsequent moves? Either direction keeps us roughly the same Manhattan distance to (8,7). However, moving RIGHT from (8,9) to (9,9) keeps us near the board’s edge while setting up easy downward movement when our tail is clear. Thus, taking RIGHT now is a good path‐planning decision.

I’ll decide to move RIGHT.

Decided next move: RIGHT.
